linesOfText.text: This is Maya.

Today she reigns as queen.
She skips around her kingdom
with a sniffer that’s supreme.

These are her princes, Horace, Ricky and Li.
They dance to scents everywhere, everywhere you see.

Today is Maya’s Day! She gathers up her friends.
“The city is our kingdom,” she blissfully pretends.

“Horace, Ricky, Li!” calls Maya, “let the games begin.”
She waves two flowers in the air and all three princes spin.

Yes, suddenly they’re princes. And Maya is their queen.
She leads them on a sniffing game across the city’s green.

But first dear Maya’s tricky
and leads them all to guess,
the scent that she is sniffing,
she will not confess.

“Do you sniff what I sniff?”
Maya prances about.
“No we don’t, Your Highness,”
all three princes shout.

“This sniff, it is the gift of
love,” Maya dashes away.

“Chocolate!” blurts out Li.
“Chocolate! Chocolate’s what I say!”

“No, not chocolate,” insists
Maya. “It grows right in the ground.”

“It’s strawberries,” offers Ricky.
“Strawberries are all around.”

“No, no,” whispers Horace before
Maya has a chance.

“Strawberries aren’t the answer.
I know this song and dance.”

Then the queen
leads her princes,

with all her
sniffing powers,

to a garden in the park
that bursts
with blooming flowers.

“Roses,” sings out Horace.
“Roses are what I sniff!”

All three princes
lean their sniffers in
to take a great big whiff.

Queen Maya
reaches for a flower
from her royal crown.

“Prince Horace,”
she declares,

“you’ve won
the first round.”

Then Maya leads
her princes beyond
the kingdom’s gate
where they rest
their royal sniffers
and patiently await.

“Do you sniff
what I sniff?”
Maya prances about.
“No we don’t,
Your Highness,”
all three princes shout.

“You eat it
at a baseball game,”
Maya drops a clue.

“Popcorn!” yelps out Li.
“Popcorn’s it.
I knew! I knew!”

“No, no,” sings Maya
as she skips
out of the park.

“But this one’s
salty too, Li.
You are on the mark.”

The four march on,
with all eight feet,
walking up
a shady street.

They stop before
a hotdog stand,
where Maya gestures
with her hand.

“Is it hotdogs?” wonders Horace,
tapping out a beat.
“But hot dogs aren’t so salty,”
he cowers in defeat.

Next Ricky steps right up,
and then he shouts with glee,
“The answer is right here,
it rests right here with me.

Come in close, take a whiff!
It’s roasted peanuts that I sniff!”

Queen Maya
reaches for a flower
from her royal crown.

“Prince Ricky,”
she declares,

“you’ve won
the second round.”

Then Maya links up
with her princes,

“To the water’s edge
we go!”

She skips across
the stripey street,
her princely
three in tow.

“Do you sniff what I sniff?”
Maya prances about.

“No we don’t, Your Highness,”
all three princes shout.

“Well, it smells like
breakfast with my pop.

He likes it sweet
with cream on top.”

All four take a seat
along the steps leading down
to a great big maple tree
with flowers all around.

“Your highness,” motions Horace,
“it’s syrup on the top.

It’s pancakes that you sniff,
pancakes for your pop!”

“No, no,“
says Ricky,
staring at the sky.

“Pancakes aren’t
Queen Maya’s sniff.
I will tell you why.

My Dad loves eggs
and buttery toast.
Now that’s the breakfast
I sniff most.”

“Not pancakes,” yelps out Li,
“no, it’s not eggs and toast.

It’s sweet with cream on top.
My papa likes it most.”

“It’s coffee, Your Highness,
my papa has a cup,
every single morning as we
watch the sun come up.”
sniff

Queen Maya
reaches for a flower
from her royal crown.

“Prince Li,”
she declares,

“you’ve won
the third round.”

Then she gathers up her princes
and leads them on their way.

And happily they follow,
for this is Maya’s Day!

“Do you sniff
what I sniff?”
Maya prances about.

“No we don’t,
Your Highness,”
all three princes shout.

“This scent
is not so pretty.

It spreads
along the streets.”

Li jumps up on his
tippy toes.

“It’s people’s
smelly feets!”

“No, no, Prince Li.
It’s something
you can eat.

But, nope! Not me.

I sniff
to my own beat.”

Then the queen
and her princes,

they skip
and skip on down
past the yellows,
pinks, and greens
of the busy, busy town,

past shoe repairs
and candy shops
and small cafes
and smiling cops.

Then Maya stops
and twirls around.

“I’ll let you sniff
what I have found.”

“I sniff it at the beach
in the middle of the day.

And that, dear princes,
is all that I can say.”

“Wait, wait, “says Li,
“I know it very well.

Fresh bread from the bakery
is all that I can smell!”

“Now, Li,” says Ricky,
“a baker at the beach?”

He turns to look at Li,
“It’s my time to teach.

The sea is full of yummy things,
yummy things to eat.”

But Horace
jumps right in,
landing on his feet.

“Fish are in the markets
and fish are out at sea.

And fish,
Queen Maya,
are what you sniff,
you see!”

Queen Maya bows to Horace
and Prince Horace, he bows back.

Then the queen and her prince
have a great big laugh attack!

“You,” Maya giggles, “have won the sniffing game.
But all of my princes, I love you just the same.”

All four grab hands
and they skip
along the streets

past the roses,
peanuts,
coffees and the fishes,
not the feets!

When they land back in the park,
Queen Maya prances about.

“Do you sniff what I sniff?”
she asks without a doubt.

“Yes, we do, Your Highness!”
all three princes shout.

“Fresh green grass is our
blanket on the ground!”

They sniff their
greeeaaatest sniff
and all four spin around.

Then they stretch and they shake
and they shimmy and they sway
and they tumble on the grass
where so happily they stay.

Then the queen and her princes,
too sleepy now to sniff,
they rest their royal bodies
without a single whiff.

But happily they dream
for they know in every way
they each brought something special
to Maya’s royal day.
The End.
